awd_titl_txt: Correlating Nanoparticle-Induced Biomembrane Perturbation with Heterogeneous Surface Chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
Engineered nanoparticles (particles of inorganic matter with a diameter on the order of tens of nanometers) have made inroads into many technology and industry sectors, from food, electronics, manufacture, consumer products, to medicine. As the use of nanoparticles continues to surge, it is critical to assess how the exposure to nanoparticles impacts human health. One major challenge, among many, is to understand the potential toxicity introduced by the surface coatings on the nanoparticles. To tackle this challenge, this research project is specifically designed to reveal the effect of non-uniform surface coatings of nanoparticles on the structure and function of biomembranes.  Nanoparticles are created to display non-uniform surface coatings that resemble engineered nanoparticles found in the environment. Investigations on the interactions between the nanoparticles and the biomembranes will provide guidelines to better predict the biological impact of industrial particles. This knowledge will also enable the design of nanoparticles with controlled surface properties, achieving desirable biological impacts. Educational and outreach activities implemented by the researchers will popularize sciences at the interface of nanotechnology and biology. The use of a "Nano-Bio Ambassadors" program, in particular, will bring nano-bioscience to students in rural communities in Indiana as well as to the general public. 

The overall objective of this project is to establish a quantitative understanding of how nanoparticles with heterogeneous surface chemistry influence the structure and function of biological membranes. Towards that goal, the researchers propose to focus on heterogeneous surfaces comprised of hydrophobic and charged groups, because this resembles the surface chemistry of industrial nanoparticles in water. Three specific aims are pursued. First, a series of amphiphilic nanoparticles that vary over a range of sizes and in hydrophilic-lipophilic balance are synthesized. Second, the disruption of such nanoparticles to the integrity and function of supported lipid bilayers is investigated and the underlying molecular mechanisms are determined. Third, the effects of membrane properties, including curvature, composition, and lipid raft formation, on interactions between amphiphilic nanoparticles and biomembranes is elucidated using the giant lipid vesicle system. Changes in lipid membranes induced by nanoparticles is mostly quantified using advanced optical and electron microscopies. Findings from this research establishes a direct connection between heterogeneous surface chemistry in nanoparticles and their perturbation to biomembranes. This study provides knowledge that is much needed but currently non-existent: a quantitative understanding of how a heterogeneous surface chemistry impacts interactions between nanoparticles and biomembranes.

Project Outcomes Report – NSF Award # 1705384

Project Title: Correlating Nanoparticle-Induced Biomembrane Perturbation with Heterogeneous Surface Chemistry

Recipient Organization: Indiana University

Project/Grant Period: 09/01/2017 - 08/31/2022

PI: Yan Yu

 

Engineered nanoparticles (particles of inorganic matter with a diameter on the order of tens of nanometers) have made inroads into many technology and industry sectors, from food, electronics, manufacture, consumer products, to medicine. As the use of nanoparticles continues to surge, it is critical to assess how the exposure to nanoparticles impacts human health. One major challenge, among many, is to understand the potential toxicity introduced by the surface coatings on the nanoparticles. Results from this research project provided new knowledge to address this challenge.

This project has resulted in a total of 9 research publications and 1 provisional patent. Collectively, findings from this project have provided a new understanding of how the surface chemistry of nanoparticles determines their biological impact. While most prior studies investigated nanoparticles with uniform surface chemistries. The nanoparticles in this project display non-uniform surface coatings that resemble engineered nanoparticles found in the environment. Results from this project revealed that such non-uniform nanoparticles perturb the biological lipid membranes, the physical barrier that separates a cell from its outside environment, by extracting lipids and collectively compressing the membrane. This new finding is significant, because it challenged the traditional view of particle-membrane interactions. The common recognition is that the overall surface chemistry of nanoparticles determines their biological impact. In contrast, this project demonstrated that the spatial arrangement of chemical groups, in addition to the overall surface chemistry, must be taken into consideration when one evaluates the biological impact of nanoparticles. For fundamental knowledge, this project broadens our understanding of the physiochemical factors that influence the biological impact of engineered nanoparticles. For translational applications, this project provides useful insights into the rationale design of more environmentally benign nanoparticles. In addition, results from this study laid the foundation for a new project on developing potent antibacterial nanoparticles that function by disrupting bacterial membranes. Part of the results was included in a provisional patent on antimicrobial nanomaterials.

In addition to the significant contribution to research and technology advancements, this project also made positive contribution to the development of human resources for the workforce. It supported the training of a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students, including a large group of women students and underrepresented minority students. The highly interdisciplinary nature of this project provides an ideal platform to prepare students as the future workforce that can tackle grand challenges across disciplines.

This project also made a broader positive impact on the education of non-science students and the general public at large. With partial support from this project, a new undergraduate course titled Chemistry of Art was successfully developed. This course is the first of its kind at Indiana University. The course curriculum was designed to help non-science major students develop a conceptual understanding of nanotechnology and bio-nano interactions. Furthermore, for outreach to the general public, this project supported hands-on educational demonstrations and activities at the Science Fest at Indiana University. The activities educated K-12 students and the general public about nanosciences.
